awd_titl_txt: RAPID: Amplifying threats during cascading crises: Media's role in shaping psychological responses to the war in Ukraine
awd_abstract_narration:
On February 24, 2022, Russia invaded Ukraine with hostile force, starting the most intense military conflict in Europe since World War II and leading to thousands of injuries and deaths and over 4 million Ukrainian refugees in the first month of the war. Reports of this international geopolitical crisis have instantaneously flooded traditional and social media outlets with graphic videos and images of injuries, death, and destruction – media coverage known to correlate with poor physical and mental health outcomes. But the Ukraine War is occurring in the broader context of the COVID-19 pandemic whose worldwide death toll exceeds 6 million people, escalating climate-related crises, economic volatility and inflation, race-driven social unrest, extreme partisanship, and low confidence in the scientific and social institutions tasked with protecting the public. Direct and media-based exposure to these unprecedented cascading collective traumas are likely to have profound effects on the mental and physical health of Americans. Effective management of these compounding crises requires policies that people support and public adoption of recommended behaviors. 

This project assesses psychological reactions to the Ukraine War among a large probability-based nationally representative sample of over 6,500 Americans from the NORC AmeriSpeak panel. They have been surveyed three times since March 2020. Early responses and beliefs about the war in Ukraine are collected as the media transitions from heavy coverage of COVID-19 to heavy coverage of the conflict. Analyses examine how intolerance for uncertainty, emotion regulation, trust in government, and social identities may explain the association between media exposure and emotional, cognitive, and behavioral responses to the war. This study investigates how fears and worries about these multiple ongoing threats are compounding negative mental health outcomes and impacting those for whom this multiplicative effect is most detrimental. Finally, this project investigates how war-related media exposure may motivate people to take positive action (e.g., prosocial behavior) to help refugees and defend Ukraine’s democracy. Embedding this project in the larger study of the COVID-19 pandemic allows examination of national responses to compounding global crises as they evolve, producing theoretically rich research with practical importance. Results inform policy makers when communicating publicly about multiple existential threats and their potential solutions so they can better promote public well-being without inducing further worry, distress, or emotional exhaustion.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
On February 24, 2022, Russia invaded Ukraine with hostile force, starting the most intense military conflict in Europe since World War II. Reports of this international geopolitical crisis instantaneously flooded traditional and social media outlets with graphic videos and images of injuries, death, and destruction. Such media exposure is known to correlate with poor physical and mental health outcomes in individuals who consume it. But the Ukraine War was also occurring within the broader context of the COVID-19 pandemic, escalating climate-related crises, economic volatility and inflation, race-driven social unrest, extreme partisanship, and low confidence in the scientific and social institutions tasked with protecting the public. Direct and media-based exposure to these unprecedented cascading collective traumas are likely to have profound effects on the mental and physical health of Americans. Effective management of these compounding crises requires policies that people support and public adoption of recommended behaviors.

This project assessed psychological reactions to the Ukraine War among a large probability-based nationally representative sample of Americans from the NORC AmeriSpeak panel. Participants had previously been surveyed three times since March 2020. Early responses and beliefs about the war in Ukraine were collected as the media transitioned from heavy coverage of COVID-19 to heavy coverage of the conflict. This study investigated how fears and worries about the many ongoing threats may intensify negative mental health symptoms, especially among those with greatest exposure to the cascading crises. In addition, this project investigated how war-related media exposure may motivate people to take positive action to help refugees (e.g., prosocial behavior) and promote democracy in Ukraine. Embedding this project in the larger study of the COVID-19 pandemic allowed examination of national responses to compounding global crises as they evolved, producing theoretically rich research with practical importance. Results can inform policy makers when communicating publicly about multiple existential threats and their potential solutions so they can better promote public well-being without inducing further worry, distress, or emotional exhaustion.

We used a probability-based sample drawn from the NORC AmeriSpeak panel with sample stratification to ensure representation across demographic characteristics. Between 3/18/2020-4/18/2020, NORC randomly sampled AmeriSpeak panelists to complete an anonymous, confidential, self-administered online survey; N=6,514 were in the final baseline sample (58.5% completion rate). Over the next two years, participants completed two additional surveys in fall, 2020 and fall, 2021. With this RAPID award funding, a fourth follow-up survey was sent to all available participants from the baseline sample (N=6,473) between 5/19/22-6/16/22; N=4,859 respondents (75.1% completion rate) were in the final sample. The final sample closely resembled the U.S. population.

Key findings from this wave of data collection include:

  • More exposure to graphic (i.e., bloody) Ukraine war media content was associated with more post-traumatic stress symptoms; exposure to non-graphic Ukraine war media content correlated with more prosocial behaviors towards Ukraine and the Ukrainian people. Also, people who more strongly identify with Ukrainian war victims and feel stronger moral outrage are at higher risk for exposure to Ukraine war media. This work underscores the importance of a balanced approach in media reporting that considers both the potential harm and benefits of graphic content dissemination, especially for those who are at higher risk of engaging with such content.
  • Cognitive strategies like finding benefits during adversity may facilitate coping by reducing distress or motivating health protective and prosocial behaviors. We explored relationships between benefit finding, collective- and individual-level adversity exposure, psychological distress, and health protective and prosocial behaviors using four waves of data collected from our longitudinal sample from the NORC AmeriSpeak panel. We found that finding benefits during collective stress may not be associated with reduced psychological distress. Nonetheless, benefit finding predicted health protective and prosocial behaviors in response to collective stressors: benefit finding was positively correlated with more social distancing and mask wearing early in the pandemic, and greater COVID-19 and flu vaccination over time. Although benefit finding did not help mitigate psychological distress, it may facilitate resilience by encouraging engagement in stress-related adaptive behaviors.
  • In the context of the COVID-19 pandemic, Americans have also been exposed to many other compounding collective stressors (e.g., war in Ukraine, climate-related disasters, mass shootings, inflation, political polarization). Shortly after the initiation of the Ukraine war, a representative sample of U.S. residents reported the highest stress for the following 5 collective stressors: inflation, mass shootings, political polarization, rising crime, and the COVID-19 pandemic. In addition, the greater the exposure to news media reports of the Ukraine War and the COVID-19 pandemic (measured over the prior 2 years), the more likely respondents were to report high stress from these combined collective experiences. Overall, compounding collective stressors were associated with poorer mental health among U.S. residents. These findings document that accelerating exposures to concurrent collective stressors may render people vulnerable to persistent mental health concerns.
